docs.title: A digital sketch grammar of Yawarana (v0.0.4)
docs.text:
This is a corpus-based, data-rich digital grammar1 sketch of Yawarana developed and written by Florian Matter in collaboration with Natalia Cáceres-Arandia and Spike Gildea. It is based on a corpus of texts, collected by Cáceres-Arandia and annotated using uniparser-yawarana.

This the mkdocs-material version.

Other available formats:

  • CLLD app
  • PDF (LaTeX)

Visit the github repo for bundled releases and the markup source.

  1. Work in progress: a guide to create your own. ↩

docs.title: Pronominal clitics
docs.text:
❕ Transitive and verbs, nouns, and postpositions share preposed sap person markers. The occurrence of bound first person u= on members of all four parts of speech is illustrated in ; illustrates the same distribution for second person më=. The 1+2 form ej= is very rare compared to the first and second person forms.

    1. irë nwa chipëkë usamori uyïpï incharë irë irë 3ana.inan nwa nwa thus chipëkë chipëkë because u =samori u =samo -ri 1=cry-ipfv u =yïpï u =yïpï -∅ 1=mountain-pert incharë in -charë see-imn ‘That's why I'm crying seeing my hills.’ ()
    2. aniki ta uyeremari aniki aniki who ta ta like u =yeremari u =-ri 1=feed-ipfv ‘Who was going to feed me then?’ ()
    3. uyarë wïrë përemekïrï u =yarë u =yarë 1=alone wïrë wïrë 1pro përemekïrï përemekï -rï talk-ipfv ‘I just talk.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 46)
    1. nwarë mëtëpëtiri, tëpëtijra sejkë nwa =rë nwa =rë thus=emp më =tëpëtiri më =-ri 2=go(PLUR)-ipfv tëpëti =jra -∅ =jra go(PLUR)-ipfv=neg sejkë be.imp ‘You're going to go like this? Don't go like this.’ ()
    2. weroro wëra këyetari mëmukuru weroro weroro dog wëra wëra like këyetari -ri grow-ipfv më =mukuru më =muku -ru 2=child-pert ‘Your children grow up like dogs.’ ()
    3. mëtojpa wïrë më =tojpa më =tojpa -∅ 2=hit-ipfv wïrë wïrë 1pro ‘I will beat you to death.’ ()
    4. ¿mëpana ma tataja wejsapë? më =pana më =pana 2=dat ma ma rst tataja ta- ta -ja 3p-say-neg wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pst ‘Didn't he say it directly to you?’ ()

When occurring on nouns and adpositions, these elements behave identically to a free pronoun by triggering the linker y-. An alternative analysis in which the person markers are prefixes would require the y occurring on nouns and postpositions to be part of the prefix, so e.g. më- / _C, mëy- / _V. However, no such y occurs on verbs . Such an analysis would therefore need to postulate that there are phonologically conditioned allomorphs on nouns and postpositions, but not on verbs. An analysis as cliticized pronominal forms does not face that issue, since the absence of y on verbs is expected by the absence of a linker on verbs.

    1. kwase mëëmpamïjpë ejnë waimu yaye kwase kwase how më =ëmpamïjpë më =ëmpamï -jpë 2=learn-pst ejnë ejnë 1+2pro waimu waimu -∅ language-pert yaye yaye loc ‘How you learned our language.’ ()
    2. mëini wïrë ya më =ini më =ini -∅ 2=see-ipfv wïrë wïrë 1pro ya ya erg ‘I will see you.’ ()

Other applicable criteria point to a clitic analysis, too (Table 3.1).

Comparison of phonologically bound person markers. Person Form Parts of speech Free counterpart y-? Stem-based allomorphy? 1 u- Vt/Vi/N/Postp wïrë + - 2 më- Vt/Vi/N/Postp mërë + - 2 a- N - + + 3 ta- Vt tëwï? - - 3 i- N/Postp - - + 3 t- N/Postp - - + 3 të- Postp tëwï - +

Interestingly, second person is much more frequently expressed by a bound form (Table 3.2).

Ratio of bound person markers compared to free pronouns. 1 2 1+2 Vt 5.04% (7/139) 93.10% (27/29) 0.00% (0/35) Vi 5.60% (7/125) 97.06% (33/34) 3.33% (2/60) N 14.61% (58/397) 95.40% (83/87) 2.35% (5/213) Postp 9.38% (3/32) 100.00% (90/90) 0.00% (0/22) Ratio of bound person markers compared to free pronouns, split by initial segment. 1 2 1+2 Vt / _C 7.53% (7/93) 100.00% (27/27) 0.00% (0/29) Vt / _V 0.00% (0/46) 0.00% (0/2) 0.00% (0/6) Vi / _C 0.00% (0/109) 97.06% (33/34) 0.00% (0/54) Vi / _V 43.75% (7/16) 33.33% (2/6) N / _C 2.91% (9/309) 96.51% (83/86) 0.00% (0/170) N / _V 55.68% (49/88) 0.00% (0/1) 11.63% (5/43) Postp / _C 0.00% (0/25) 100.00% (90/90) 0.00% (0/21) Postp / _V 42.86% (3/7) 0.00% (0/1)

docs.title: The Yawarana people and their language
Previous studies on the Yawarana language
Variation
docs.text:
Some corners of Yawarana grammar are subject to variation:

  • vowel system (2.1.2)
  • plural marking (10)
  • constituent order (16)
  • presence or absence of the ergative marker ya (13)

docs.title: Multiclausal
docs.text:
Historically, the function of subordinate clauses was covered by nominalizations and adverbializations. For instance, a meaning like 'after I slept, I ate' was expressed as 'after my sleeping', the verb being a noun syntactically, followed by a postposition.

  • status in matrix clause:

    • argument of the matrix clause
    • adverbial adjunct
    • relative clause

  • differences & similarities to simple verb clauses?

  • order of arguments re: the verb (and each other)
  • case marking patterns
  • indexation
  • clausal particles
  • +mapping between matrix and subordinate

docs.title: Negation
docs.text:
There are a number of negation strategies in Yawarana. The most general negator is the particle =jra, which can negate a number of constructions. It occurs encliticized to transitive and intransitive verbs , nouns , adverbs , and postpositions .

    1. kukurujra tëwï kukuru =jra kuku -ru =jra answer-ipfv=neg tëwï tëwï 3pro ‘They didn't answer.’ ()
    2. uyarë wïrë wïnïkïrïjra u =yarë u =yarë 1=alone wïrë wïrë 1pro wïnïkïrï =jra wïnïkï -rï =jra sleep-ipfv=neg ‘I did not sleep apart.’ ()
    3. aaa, ijtarijra ta aaa aaa ah ijtari =jra i- jta -ri =jra 3-foot-pert=neg ta ta like ‘Ah, without his legs.’ ()
    4. entë ma teijpojra wejtane entë entë here.loc ma ma rst teijpo =jra teijpo =jra far=neg wejtane wej -tane cop-cncs ‘Although it is close to here.’ ()
    5. toto waimu yayejra toto toto non_Indian waimu waimu -∅ language-pert yaye =jra yaye =jra loc=neg ‘Not in Spanish.’ ()

On verbs, it sometimes occurs with an overt allomorph of -ri , sometimes its zero allomorph, shown in .

  1. wïrë wajyakïtïjra taro wïrë ta wïrë ya wïrë wïrë 1pro wajyakïtï =jra wajyakïtï -∅ =jra be_happy-ipfv=neg taro taro -∅ say-ipfv wïrë wïrë 1pro ta ta -∅ say-ipfv wïrë wïrë 1pro ya ya erg ‘I’m saying I am not happy.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 24)

This variation is found in other contexts as well, but the conditioning factors of the deletion are currently unknown (see 6.2.1). However, in the case of jra, it may occur for a different reason entirely. Historically, a verb suffixed with *-rï and followed by a particle *pïra was a distinct construction from a verb with an adverbializing negative suffix *-pïra and followed by a copula (Gildea and Meira 2016, Cáceres 2016).

docs.title: Pronouns
docs.text:
The personal pronouns of Yawarana are shown in Table 4.1. The system shows the usual Cariban inclusive/exclusive (1+2 and 1+3) distinction, though the 1+2 pronoun ejnë does not have the /k/ found elsewhere in the family. There are plural forms of the second and third person pronouns, which are composed of the respective singular form and the plural marker kontomo for second, -santomo for third person. An alternative strategy for pluralizing tëwï is by using jne. This results in tëwï=jne, which usually simply becomes ta=jne. Singular speech act participant pronouns can procliticize to nouns (see 4.4), verbs (see 13) and postpositions (see 7.4).

Pronouns sg pl 1 wïrë (u=) 1+2 ejnë (ej=) 1+3 ana 2 mërë (më=) monkontomo 3 tëwï tëwïsantomo

The third person demonstrative pronouns or articles are shown in Table 4.2. ❔ None of them have shortened and phonologically bound counterparts. ❔

Demonstrative pronouns / articles anim inan sg pl sg pl prox kërë kërësantomo eni / seni eni=jne / seni=jne medial/near? michi / misi michisantomo / michitomo mërë mërë=jne dist mëjkï mëkïsantomo mëjnï mënï=jne
  • nominal interrogative pronouns: ❔
    • anïkï (pl with -santomo)
    • ati (no pl)

docs.title: Nominal inflection
docs.text: Nouns in Yawarana may bear suffixes marking their possession status (4.3.1), number (4.3.2), and nominal past tense (4.3.3). Possessed nouns can carry second and third person prefixes, as well as the linker y- (4.3.4). ❕

docs.title: Suffixes for possessed and non-possessed nouns
docs.text:
In the possession construction in Yawarana, the possessor noun occurs immediately preceding the possessed noun, which is the head of the possession phrase. ❕ Alternatively, the possessor can appear as a prefix on the possessed noun. The possessor noun is never marked (for instance, with genitive case), but the possessed noun (the head) is often marked for being possessed by a suffix; an unambiguous label for this counterpart of the genitive is pertensive (Dixon 2010). The choice of suffix is lexically conditioned; while most nouns take -ri, some take -ti. Unpossessed nouns generally are unmarked, but some 15 nouns ❕ bear the suffix -të when they appear without a possessor.

Examples illustrate the possible patterns of markedness for nouns when possessed and unpossessed. The vast majority of nouns in our corpus are unmarked when unpossessed, but when possessed the suffix -ri occurs . A handful of nouns is marked with -ri/-ti when possessed and with -të when not possessed . Another handful is unmarked when possessed and marked with -të when not possessed . The fourth logical category, where neither possession or non-possession is marked, contains very few members (only one attested so far). For these nouns, the difference is marked only by the presence or absence of a possessive prefix or free-form possessor . ❕

  1. Nouns that take a suffix only when possessed: akajra-ri ‘X’s bow’ akajra ‘bow’ y-amaka-ri ‘X’s yucca’ amaka ‘yucca’ y-ántë-ri ‘X’s fishhook’ antë ‘fishhook’ y-ateri-ri ‘X’s garden/field’ ateri ‘garden/field’ ënu-ru ‘X’s eye’ ënu ‘eye’ y-ëpi-ri ‘X’s medicine’ ëpi ‘medicine’
  1. Nouns that take one suffix when possessed and another when unpossessed: yë-ri ‘X’s tooth’ yë-të ‘tooth’ pata-ri ‘X’s place’ pata-të ‘(part of name) San Juan de Manapiare’ y-ese-ti ‘X’s name’ ese-të ‘name’ y-ase-tï ‘X’s cord’ ase-të ‘cord’
  1. Nouns that take a suffix only when unpossessed: yëjpë ‘X’s bone’ yëjpë-të ‘bone’ petï ‘X’s thigh’ petï-të / pej-të ‘thigh’ y-aponi ‘X’s stool’ apon-të ‘stool’
  1. Nouns that never take a suffix, whether possessed or unpossessed: i-jmëy ‘his egg’ ëjmëy ‘egg’

docs.title: Nominal number
docs.text:
The suffix -tomo (-tom, -ton) occurs on both possessed and unpossessed nouns .

    1. wurijyantomo rë wejsapë ijtë wurijyantomo wurijyan -tomo woman-pl rë rë emp wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pst ijtë ijtë there ‘There were only women there.’ ()
    2. tajne nankase takerejtomo ya ta =jne ta =jne 3pro=pl nankase nanka -se find-pst takerejtomo t- akere -j -tomo 3-relative-pert-pl ya ya erg ‘His relatives found him.’ ()

docs.title: Inflectional prefixes
docs.text:
There are three inflectional prefixal morphemes on nouns (Table 4.3); only two of them are possessive prefixes, the third being the linker. Prefix allomorphy is mainly conditioned by the initial segment of the noun root.

Inflectional prefixes on nouns _C _V 2 a- / ë- ay- 3 i- t- np y-

Second person a(y)- only occurs on a small number of nouns, all of them kinship terms (Table 4.4). With other nouns (and for all first and first person inclusive possessors), a pronominal form is used (see 4.4). None of the stems in Table 4.4 is attested with a pronominal second person possessor.

Nouns taking second person _a(y)-_. Stem Meaning sanë ‘mother’ awo ‘uncle, father in law’ najmo ‘grandmother’ ya’ra ‘grandchild’ akono ‘younger sister of woman’ wanene ‘aunt’

The third person prefix has the allomorphs i- and t-:

  1. mmm, imukuru ma mmm mmm yes imukuru i- muku -ru 3-child-pert ma ma rst ‘Yes, his son.’ ()
  1. tapëri tapëri t- apë -ri 3-arm_wing-pert ‘Her arm?’ ()

The linking prefix y- only occurs on V-initial nouns. It marks them as being preceded by their possessor . C-initial (and i-initial) nouns do not show a prefix in this context . This pattern is shared by postpositions (see 7).

  1. ati ke ejnë yoti yamanë wejsapë tëwï ati ati what ke ke ins ejnë ejnë 1+2pro yoti y- oti -∅ lk-meat-pert yamanë yamanë -∅ make-ipfv wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pst tëwï tëwï 3pro ‘With that we used to prepare the meat.’ ()
    1. mëinta yaka më =inta më =inta -∅ 2=mouth-pert yaka yaka all ‘into your mouth’ ()
    2. muku pana yënënijpë ti muku muku child pana pana -∅ ear-pert yënënijpë yënë -ni -jpë eat(meat)-agtnmlz-pst ti ti hsy ‘The one who ate a child's ear, so they say.’ ()

docs.title: The noun phrase
docs.text:
A constituent we call the noun phrase is identifiable in the genitive construction in which one noun (or pronoun) possesses another noun. For instance, pana in is possessed by muku. The possessor obligatorily precedes the possessum, the two parts of the constituent only being interruptible by certain particles . Possessor SAP pronouns can occur as proclitics . On V-initial nouns, the linker y- appears in the genitive construction.

  1. muku pana yënënijpë ti muku muku child pana pana -∅ ear-pert yënënijpë yënë -ni -jpë eat(meat)-agtnmlz-pst ti ti hsy ‘The one who ate a child's ear, so they say.’ ()
  1. takonojpë rë yapijtontomo ya, najpïtom pan yakono wïrë inijpë chipëkën takï wïrë taro takonojpë takono -jpë other-pst rë rë emp yapijtontomo yapijton -tomo old-pl ya ? najpïtom najpï -tom grandfather-pl pan pan fmr yakono y- akono -∅ lk-younger_sister_of_woman-pert wïrë wïrë 1pro inijpë ini -jpë see-pst chipëkën chipëkën because takï takï cnfrm wïrë wïrë 1pro taro taro -∅ say-ipfv ‘The last old ones, the younger brother of my grandparents, because I saw them, I say so.’ ()
    1. ¡këë! uyejwetunu, ¡këë! wïrë waijtëri, ¡këë! uyapëri, wïrë poreri, wïrë chikimuru këë këë ugh u =yejwetunu u =y- ejwetunu -∅ 1=lk-sick-pert këë këë ugh wïrë wïrë 1pro waijtëri waijtë -ri head-pert këë këë ugh u =yapëri u =y- apë -ri 1=lk-arm_wing-pert wïrë wïrë 1pro poreri pore -ri leg-pert wïrë wïrë 1pro chikimuru chikimu -ru knee-pert ‘Ugh! I'm sick, ugh, my head, ugh, my arm, my leg, my knee.’ ()
    2. mëwaijtë yaka wëjkase më =waijtë më =waijtë -∅ 2=head-pert yaka yaka all wëjkase wëjka -se fall-pst ‘It went into your head.’ ()
  1. uyïwïj yawë usenejkari sukuri jwama u =yïwïj u =y- ïwïj -∅ 1=lk-house-pert yawë yawë loc u =senejkari u =-ri 1=stay-ipfv sukuri sukuri silently jwama *** ‘I silently stay in my house.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 28)
  1. tïwïj yaka waraijtokomo manikijpë tïwïj t- ïwïj -∅ 3-house-pert yaka yaka all waraijtokomo waraijtokomo man manikijpë *** ‘The man went to his house.’ (Cuento de las ratas por AnFo : 46)
  1. marë wïrë sëmpinukuja rë wejtane mokontomo unono, wïrë nono yenekapëkë pako marë marë still wïrë wïrë 1pro sëmpinukuja sëmpinuku -ja close_eyes-neg rë rë emp wejtane wej -tane cop-cncs mokontomo mokontomo 2pl.pro u =nono u =nono -∅ 1=earth-pert wïrë wïrë 1pro nono nono -∅ earth-pert yenekapëkë yeneka -pëkë take_away-prog.tr pako *** ‘Though I haven't closed my eyes yet, you are already taking my land from me.’ ()
  1. yapijtompe wïrë wejtane, ¡kë! wïyapë moroni yapijtom =pe yapijtom =pe old=ess wïrë wïrë 1pro wejtane wej -tane cop-cncs kë kë ugh wï =yapë wï =y- apë -∅ 1=lk-arm_wing-pert moroni moroni pain ‘Although I am old, ugh, my arms hurt.’ ()
  1. ë'ë, mëyakereti ëʼë ëʼë yes më =yakereti më =y- akere -ti 2=lk-relative-pert ‘Yes, your family.’ ()
  1. kwase neke wejsapë tëwï ma anajmori ya yakarama wejsapë kwase kwase how neke neke cntr wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pst tëwï tëwï 3pro ma ma rst anajmori a- najmo -ri 2-grandmother-pert ya ya erg yakarama -∅ tell-ipfv wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pst ‘what it was like, that's all your grandmother said.’ ()
  1. pïrarë ti iwenaru wejsapë pïrarë pïrarë neg.exist ti ti hsy iwenaru i- wena -ru 3-vomit-pert wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pst ‘their vomit was not there.’ (Cuento de las ratas por AnFo : 19)
  1. wïrë yapëri moronta chi taji wïrë wïrë 1pro yapëri y- apë -ri lk-arm_wing-pert moronta -∅ hurt-ipfv chi chi -∅ cop-ipfv taji taji foc ‘My arms hurt.’ ()
  1. ¡këë! uyejwetunu, ¡këë! wïrë waijtëri, ¡këë! uyapëri, wïrë poreri, wïrë chikimuru këë këë ugh u =yejwetunu u =y- ejwetunu -∅ 1=lk-sick-pert këë këë ugh wïrë wïrë 1pro waijtëri waijtë -ri head-pert këë këë ugh u =yapëri u =y- apë -ri 1=lk-arm_wing-pert wïrë wïrë 1pro poreri pore -ri leg-pert wïrë wïrë 1pro chikimuru chikimu -ru knee-pert ‘Ugh! I'm sick, ugh, my head, ugh, my arm, my leg, my knee.’ ()
  1. asakërërë mëyawajkë, asakë mëyumukunu asakërë =rë asakërë =rë two=emp më =yawajkë më =yawaj -kë 2=grate-imp asakë asakë two më =yumukunu më =y- umukunu -∅ 2=lk-hand-pert ‘Scrape with both, two hands.’ ()
  1. aaa, mëyakerej sëmase, ¡aj! inche utërijra aaa aaa ah më =yakerej më =y- akere -j 2=lk-relative-pert sëmase sëma -se die-pst aj aj ah inche in -che see-sup u =tëri =jra u =të -ri =jra 1=go-ipfv=neg ‘Ah, your family is dead, ah, I will not go see.’ ()

The linker also occurs with (pro-)nominal possessors:

  1. toto yoti tajtoj mare toto toto non_Indian yoti y- oti -∅ lk-meat-pert tajtoj taj -toj say-circ.nmlz mare mare rel.inan ‘What they call the food of the criollos.’ ()

docs.title: Nominal Derivational Morphology
docs.text:
• V → N
    • -ri ❕
    • -jpë
      • also ‘pst.abs.nmlz)’ ❕
    • -në or ‘generic action nominalizer’ ❕
      • wënkej-në from transitive wënkepï 'forget'
    • -ni ❕

docs.title: Number
docs.text:
There are several pluralization strategies for nouns, the only inflectional one using the suffix -tomo. It can be combined with the plural particle jne ; this particle can also be the only exponent of plural .

  1. wïrë najpïtomojne, wurijyantomojne sënka wara rë wïrë wïrë 1pro najpïtomo =jne najpï -∅ -tomo =jne grandfather-pert-pl=pl wurijyantomo =jne wurijyan -tomo =jne woman-pl=pl sënka -∅ finish-acnnmlz wara wara thus rë rë emp ‘My grandfathers, the women disappeared.’ ()
  1. tipapëjsejne waijtajne tipapëjse =jne tipa -pëj -se =jne go_in_group-plur-pst=pl waijta =jne waijta =jne mouse=pl ‘The mice went away.’ (Cuento de las ratas por AnFo : 40)

There is also the particle kontomo, which marks plurality of the possessor . Etymologically, it consists of an earlier *komo suffixed with -tomo.

  1. chimakontomo chima =kontomo chima =kontomo path=pl ‘their path’ ()

In many nouns, old plural markers have become lexicalized, like in wiriyamo or waraijtokomo, which show former *-yamë and *komo.

docs.title: Transitive clauses
docs.text:
There are several factors that play a role here:

  1. presence or absence of prefix
  2. presence or absence of pronouns and NPs
  3. order of free arguments
  4. presence or absence of ya

docs.title: Third on third
docs.text:
1. preverbal pronoun with ya tëwï ya nepïjpë wejsapë tëwï tëwï 3pro ya ya erg nepïjpë nepï -jpë bring-pst wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pst ‘He brought it.’ ()

❕

docs.title: Classes of verbs
docs.text:
Yawarana verb roots can be divided into those yielding an intransitive stem, and those yielding a transitive stem. The only inflectional criterion distinguishing the two classes is the third person prefix ta-, which only occurs (optionally, see 6.1) on transitive stems. Thus, transitive yawanka takes ta- , but intransitive yaruwa does not . ❔

    1. iyawë chipëkë, tayawankase iyawë i- yawë 3-loc chipëkë chipëkë because tayawankase ta- yawanka -se 3p-kill-pst ‘Because of this, he killed her.’ ()
    2. yaruwakontomo yatum ponoko yaruwa =kontomo yaruwa -∅ =kontomo laugh-ipfv=pl yatum yatum day ponoko *** ‘They laugh every day.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 42)
  • potential additional verb classes:
    • detransitive
    • ditransitive
    • "n-adding"
    • accidental lability
    • irregular 'to go'
  • all transitive verbs are C‑ or i-initial because of the fossilization of y-
  • said y‑ disappears when preceded by the detransitivizer ❕

docs.title: Verbal inflection
docs.text: There is a range of TAM suffixes, as well as one third person prefix.

docs.title: The third person prefix ta-
docs.text:
The only inflectional morphology is a third person prefix ta-. It only occurs on transitive verbs, and seems to be restricted to 3>3 scenarios, i.e. when a third person referent is acting on another third person referent . However, it is not obligatory . Also, it can cooccur with free noun phrases referencing either the A or the P . The conditioning factors for its (non-)occurrence in 3>3 scenarios are unknown. Note that the free pronouns wïrë, mërë and ejnë (4.2) can occur in the same location as ta-, but also on intransitive verbs (see 13). ❔

    1. tainiri tainiri ta- ini -ri 3p-see-ipfv ‘He saw it.’ ()
    2. inijpë tawara, inijpë inijpë ini -jpë see-pst tawara tawara too inijpë ini -jpë see-pst ‘They saw it too, they saw it.’ ()
    3. asanë tanëmëse mërë nono mokontomo warotatojpe asanë a- sanë -∅ 2-mother-pert tanëmëse ta- nëmë -se 3p-leave-pst mërë mërë 2pro nono nono -∅ earth-pert mokontomo mokontomo 2pl.pro warotatojpe warota -tojpe work-purp ‘Your mother left your land for you to work on.’ ()

docs.title: Main clause tense‑aspect‑mood‑polarity suffixes
docs.text:
Verbs in main clauses are inflected for TAMP with a set of suffixes, shown in Table 6.1. They are discussed in 6.2.1; for a detailed overview of past markers see Cáceres & Gildea (2022) ❕.

Verbal TAM suffixes Suffix Function -ri imperfective -jpë past -se past perfective -sapë perfect -sarë imminent future -nëpëkë progressive (intr) pëkë progressive (tr) ‑tojpano future (-tojpe) future -ja negation -se-mï obligation -në impersonal S -topo ? Non-declarative suffixes Suffix Function ‑jrama prohibitive -i jussive -kë imperative -ta motion imperative

❕

docs.title: The imperfective -ri
docs.text:
• allomorphy:
    • most conservative form: -rï
    • /ï/ > /i/ (2.1.2): -ri
    • phonetic loss: -∅ (2.2.1)
      • inconsistent zero before jra, see 9
      • consistent zero before kontomo
    • assimilation: -ru (2.2.2)
  • diachrony: from -ri (4.5.1)
  • plural: kontomo
  • negation: jra , but potentially two distinct etymologies ❔
  • semantics:
    • not specified for tense, only imperfective aspect:
      • past
      • future
      • gnomic/present?
  1. irëjpë tëwï waijtatomo nwajtëri irëjpë irëjpë then tëwï tëwï 3pro waijtatomo waijta -tomo mouse-pl nwajtëri nwajtë -ri dance-ipfv ‘Then the mice were dancing.’ (Cuento de las ratas por AnFo : 16)
  1. ¿kwase ejnë yaruwari? kwase kwase how ejnë ejnë 1+2pro yaruwari yaruwa -ri laugh-ipfv ‘How will we laugh?’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 6)
    1. wïrë yaruwarijra wïrë wïrë 1pro yaruwari =jra yaruwa -ri =jra laugh-ipfv=neg ‘I don’t laugh.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 4)
    2. uyïwïj yawë usenejkari sukuri jwama u =yïwïj u =y- ïwïj -∅ 1=lk-house-pert yawë yawë loc u =senejkari u =-ri 1=stay-ipfv sukuri sukuri silently jwama *** ‘I silently stay in my house.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 28)

docs.text:
• allomorphy: none?
  • semantics: unclear ❕
  • diachrony: from -jpë (4.5.2)
  • negated with jra
  • plural: kontomo
  1. tëwïsantomo wïrë wejyatë këyetajpëjra tëwïsantomo tëwï -santomo 3pro-pl wïrë wïrë 1pro wejyatë wejyatë in_house_of këyetajpë =jra -jpë =jra grow-pst=neg ‘They did not grow up with me.’ ()
  1. ¿kwase ne wepïjpëkonton ti? ta kwase =ne kwase =ne how=ints wepïjpë =konton wepï -jpë =konton come-pst=pl ti ti hsy ta ta -∅ say-ipfv ‘"How did they come?", s/he says.’ ()

docs.title: -se
docs.text:
• allomorphy: -se/-che (2.2.3)
  • diachrony: from -se ❔
  • negation: replaced with -ja (see also 9.1.1)
  • plural: kontomo and jne
  • semantics: unclear ❔
  1. wëjkaja, ana tëse neke ne wëjkaja wëjka -ja fall-neg ana ana 1+3pro tëse të -se go-pst neke =ne neke =ne cntr=ints ‘We didn't fall, we went away.’ ()
  1. tipapëjsejne waijtajne tipapëjse =jne tipa -pëj -se =jne go_in_group-plur-pst=pl waijta =jne waijta =jne mouse=pl ‘The mice went away.’ (Cuento de las ratas por AnFo : 40)
  1. tipasekontomo warë irëjpë pïrarë tipase =kontomo tipa -se =kontomo go_in_group-pst=pl wa =rë wa =rë thus=emp irëjpë irëjpë then pïrarë pïrarë neg.exist ‘They left and were gone.’ (Cuento de las ratas por AnFo : 30)

docs.title: -sapë
docs.text:
• diachrony: from -sapë (4.5.3)
  • allomorphy: -sapë and -saj (2.2.1)
  • negation: with -ja on lexical verb
  • plural: kontomo

❔

  1. irë wejtane mujyampe patakaja wejsapë irë irë 3ana.inan wejtane wej -tane cop-cncs mujyam =pe mujyam =pe pregnancy=ess patakaja -ja take_out-neg wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pst ‘Despite this, she did not get pregnant.’ ()
  1. apatakaja pïnïka wejsapë apatakaja -ja come_out-neg pïnïka pïnïka prob wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pst ‘Maybe she did not come out (pregnant).’ ()
  1. tayakïjtëja pïnika wejsapë tayakïjtëja ta- yakïjtë -ja 3p-sleep_with-neg pïnika pïnika prob wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pst ‘Maybe he didn't sleep with her.’ ()
  1. ¿ësëpëkë ka wejsapëkontomo? ësëpëkë ësë- pëkë detrz-about ka ka q wejsapë =kontomo wej -sapë =kontomo cop-pst=pl ‘Were they always argumenting?’ ()

docs.title: -sarë
docs.text:
• once a converb, now 'imminent future'
  • allomorphy: -charë (2.2.3)
  • negation: ?
  • semantics: ?
  • plural: ?
  1. irëjpë ta ti ta konopo wejsarë konopo wejsarë irëjpë irëjpë then ta ta -∅ say-ipfv ti ti hsy ta ta like konopo konopo rain wejsarë wej -sarë come-imn konopo konopo rain wejsarë wej -sarë come-imn ‘Then they said: “it’s raining, it’s raining”.’ (Cuento de las ratas por AnFo : 25)
  1. ejnë waimu wintikasarë ta rë ejnë ejnë 1+2pro waimu waimu -∅ language-pert wintikasarë wintika -sarë disappear-imn ta ta like rë rë emp ‘Our language is disappearing.’ ()

docs.title: Subordinate Clause markers
docs.text:
❕

  • Nominalizations
    • -ri
    • -jpë
    • -topo
  • Adverbial Clauses (S/A)
    • -se
    • -tane
    • -sarë
    • ‑yapo ‘neg.purp’
    • others?
  • Nominalization + postposition (S/P)
    • -∅yawë
    • -∅ pe ‘when’
    • -sajyawë
    • -tojpe
    • (‑jpë)=tërë ‘after’
    • on auxiliary: -ri + po 'ctrf'
  • not attested:
    • se 'des'
    • -ajtawï 'if when'

docs.title: Number
docs.text:
The main number marking strategy for verbs uses the particle kontomo, which usually encliticizes to the verb. It occurs with all major TAM suffixes .

    1. yajtëpe neke n ti warotakontomo wejsapë yajtëpe yajtëpe before neke =n neke =n cntr=ints ti ti hsy warota =kontomo warota -∅ =kontomo work-ipfv=pl wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pst ‘At the beginning they worked.’ ()
    2. ¿irëjpë, wepïjpëkontomo? irëjpë irëjpë then wepïjpë =kontomo wepï -jpë =kontomo come-pst=pl ‘Then they came?’ ()
    3. ¿epesekontomo? epese =kontomo epe -se =kontomo escape-pst=pl ‘Did they escape?’ ()
    4. irë wa chipëkë tapojtëja wejsapë, irë wa chipëkë tajne wëpëjse tëwï, sukase wïnïjsajkonton yawë irë irë 3ana.inan wa wa thus chipëkë chipëkë because tapojtëja ta- pojtë -ja 3p-want-neg wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pst irë irë 3ana.inan wa wa thus chipëkë chipëkë because ta =jne ta =jne 3pro=pl wëpëjse wë -pëj -se kill-plur-pst tëwï tëwï 3pro sukase sukase all wïnïjsaj =konton wïnïj -saj =konton sleep-pfv=pl yawë yawë loc ‘That's why I didn't want it, that's why they killed them all when they were asleep.’ ()
  • verbal plural patterns:
    • -ri=kontomo
    • -sapë=kontomo
    • -saj-se=jne
    • -se=jne=kontomo
    • -të-kë for the imperative
    • what about -i ‘juss’?

docs.title: Copula / Auxiliary
docs.text:
• there is (synchronically suppletive) stem allomorphy: chi and wej

TBD:

  1. add a paradigm of the copula
  2. find potential particles developed from inflected forms: man, wai, manai, etc
  3. are there irregular past/perfect participles? nahkë, etc?
  4. ejnë may come from an inflected form of the copula

docs.title: Detransitive voice
docs.text:
• functions of detrz:
    • antipassive
    • passive
    • reflexive
    • reciprocal
    • anticausative
  • other strategies for removing participant:
    • -se-mï 'gnomic'
    • -në
  • what is not used for voice?
    • -sapë
    • participle

docs.title: Issues with transitivity
docs.text:
• ya occurs with intransitives
  • some transitive verbs occur with oblique-marked P arguments:
  1. ati rë warai mërë iniri, irëjpë mëyarika ti ati ati what rë rë emp warai warai like mërë mërë 2pro iniri ini -ri see-ipfv irëjpë irëjpë then më =yarika më =yarika -∅ 2=laugh-ipfv ti ti hsy ‘You see something and then you laugh.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 1)
  • some intransitive verbs can look like transitives:
  1. ¿ati ejnë yaruwari? ati ati what ejnë ejnë 1+2pro yaruwari yaruwa -ri laugh-ipfv ‘What are we going to laugh about?’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 12)
  • not all transitive verbs take identifiable objects:
  1. wïrë inija ta rë wïrë wïrë 1pro inija ini -ja see-neg ta ta like rë rë emp ‘I haven’t seen.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 44)

docs.title: Transitive clauses
docs.text:
• clear tendency for VCop (as opposed to CopV)
  1. wïrë inija tëwï wïrë wïrë 1pro inija ini -ja see-neg tëwï tëwï 3pro ‘I did not see that.’ ()

  • Yawarana ajpachike ‘weeded‘ (Mattéi-Müller and Cáceres Arandia 2023)

  • Yawarana arokatë ‘difficult‘ (Mattéi-Müller and Cáceres Arandia 2023)

  • Yawarana asakë ‘two‘ (Mattéi-Müller and Cáceres Arandia 2023)
  • Yawarana jne ‘PL‘ (Mattéi-Müller and Cáceres Arandia 2023)

docs.title: Texts
docs.text:
• Historia personal por AnFo
  • Cuento de las ratas por AnFo
  • Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe

docs.title: Text: Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe
docs.text:
1. ati rë warai mërë iniri, irëjpë mëyarika ti ati ati what rë rë emp warai warai like mërë mërë 2pro iniri ini -ri see-ipfv irëjpë irëjpë then më =yarika më =yarika -∅ 2=laugh-ipfv ti ti hsy ‘You see something and then you laugh.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 1)
  1. mëyaruwari, mëpëkëpene më =yaruwari më =yaruwa -ri 2=laugh-ipfv më =pëkëpene më =pëkëpene 2=alone ‘You just laugh.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 2)
  1. ejnë pëkëpene ejnë yaruwaja, ënka wanene ejnë ejnë 1+2pro pëkëpene pëkëpene alone ejnë ejnë 1+2pro yaruwaja yaruwa -ja laugh-neg ënka ënka right wanene wanene aunt ‘We don’t just laugh, right, aunt?’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 3)
  1. wïrë yaruwarijra wïrë wïrë 1pro yaruwari =jra yaruwa -ri =jra laugh-ipfv=neg ‘I don’t laugh.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 4)
  1. ejnë yaruwari tajne yakarama pëkë rë nwarë, nope esene mare, tawara neke ne, ënka ejnë ejnë 1+2pro yaruwari yaruwa -ri laugh-ipfv ta =jne ta =jne 3pro=pl yakarama -∅ tell-acnnmlz pëkë pëkë about rë rë emp nwa =rë nwa =rë thus=emp nope nope good esene -∅ see_self-ipfv mare mare rel.inan tawara tawara too neke neke cntr ne *** ënka ënka right ‘We laugh when somebody tells (us) something, something you see well, like that, right.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 5)
  1. ¿kwase ejnë yaruwari? kwase kwase how ejnë ejnë 1+2pro yaruwari yaruwa -ri laugh-ipfv ‘How will we laugh?’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 6)
  1. wïrë yaruwakempïnirë, mëkïsantomo a-ja-ja tajtane wïrë wïrë 1pro yaruwakem =pïnirë yaruwa -∅ -ke -m =pïnirë laugh-acnnmlz-prop-nmlz=neg mëkïsantomo mëkï -santomo dist.anim-pl a-ja-ja *** tajtane taj -tane say-cncs ‘I don’t laugh although they are saying “hahaha”.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 7)
  1. ¡kï! ¿mokontomo serekapojra ka mokontomo yaruwari? wïrë yaruwarijra taro wïrë, ta ta wïrë ya kï kï ugh mokontomo mokontomo 2pl.pro serekapo =jra -po -∅ =jra become_tired-des-ipfv=neg ka ka q mokontomo mokontomo 2pl.pro yaruwari yaruwa -ri laugh-ipfv wïrë wïrë 1pro yaruwari =jra yaruwa -ri =jra laugh-ipfv=neg taro taro -∅ say-ipfv wïrë wïrë 1pro ta ta -∅ say-ipfv ta ta like wïrë wïrë 1pro ya ya erg ‘Oh! You don’t get tired of laughing? I don’t laugh, is what I’m saying.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 8)
  1. tëwï neke ne, tajne yakarama pokono nwarë tajne iri mïntë, tunampe tëwï tëwï 3pro neke neke cntr ne *** ta =jne ta =jne 3pro=pl yakarama -∅ tell-acnnmlz pokono poko -no about-nmlz nwa =rë nwa =rë thus=emp ta =jne ta =jne 3pro=pl iri i -ri put-ipfv mïntë mïntë there.loc tunam =pe tunam -∅ =pe hide-acnnmlz=ess ‘Yes indeed, they tell what they are doing there on the down-low.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 9)
  1. tajne yarikari irëjpë, tajne yakarama pokono ta =jne ta =jne 3pro=pl yarikari yarika -ri laugh-ipfv irëjpë irëjpë then ta =jne ta =jne 3pro=pl yakarama -∅ tell-acnnmlz pokono poko -no about-nmlz ‘They laugh because they tell it.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 10)
  1. tawaja ejnë, ejnë neke ne, ejnë pëkëpene ejnë yarikaja tawaja tawaja thus.neg ejnë ejnë 1+2pro ejnë ejnë 1+2pro neke neke cntr ne *** ejnë ejnë 1+2pro pëkëpene pëkëpene alone ejnë ejnë 1+2pro yarikaja yarika -ja laugh-neg ‘We’re not like that, we don’t just laugh.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 11)
  1. ¿ati ejnë yaruwari? ati ati what ejnë ejnë 1+2pro yaruwari yaruwa -ri laugh-ipfv ‘What are we going to laugh about?’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 12)
  1. pïrarë, seneja ejnë yarikatopo pïrarë pïrarë neg.exist seneja -ja see_self-neg ejnë ejnë 1+2pro yarikatopo yarika -topo laugh-circ.nmlz ‘Nothing, there’s nothing for us to laugh.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 13)
  1. nwarë ti ta ta nwa =rë nwa =rë thus=emp ti ti hsy ta ta -∅ say-ipfv ta ta like ‘That’s what they said (?)’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 14)
  1. taitapo ti taitapo ta- ita -po -∅ 3p-hear-des-ipfv ti ti hsy ‘I want to hear it.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 15)
  1. ¿ati ta ta? ati ati what ta ta -∅ say-ipfv ta ta like ‘What are you saying?’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 16)
  1. chiri ma wïrë taro chiri chi -ri cop-acnnmlz ma ma rst wïrë wïrë 1pro taro taro -∅ say-ipfv ‘That’s all I’m saying.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 17)
  1. tawarama taro wïrë, wïrë yewenke tawara =ma tawara =ma too=rst taro taro -∅ say-ipfv wïrë wïrë 1pro wïrë wïrë 1pro yewenke y- ewenke lk-ignorant ‘That’s all I’m saying, too, I don’t know.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 18)
  1. ¿ati pëkë ejnë yaruwari? ati ati what pëkë pëkë about ejnë ejnë 1+2pro yaruwari yaruwa -ri laugh-ipfv ‘What are we going to laugh about?’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 19)
  1. yaruwakempïnirë wïrë yaruwakem =pïnirë yaruwa -∅ -ke -m =pïnirë laugh-acnnmlz-prop-nmlz=neg wïrë wïrë 1pro ‘I don’t laugh.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 20)
  1. wïrë yaruwakempïnirë wïrë senejkarï uyïwïj yaka sukuri, jwama wïrë wïrë 1pro yaruwakem =pïnirë yaruwa -∅ -ke -m =pïnirë laugh-acnnmlz-prop-nmlz=neg wïrë wïrë 1pro senejkarï -rï stay-ipfv u =yïwïj u =y- ïwïj -∅ 1=lk-house-pert yaka yaka all sukuri sukuri silently jwama *** ‘I don’t laugh, I silently stay in my house.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 21)
  1. mëkïsantomo yaruwari wïrë itari mëkïsantomo mëkï -santomo dist.anim-pl yaruwari yaruwa -ri laugh-ipfv wïrë wïrë 1pro itari ita -ri hear-ipfv ‘They’re laughing and I’m listening.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 22)
  1. kï, serekapojra ka mokontomo yaruwari kï kï ugh serekapo =jra -po -∅ =jra become_tired-des-ipfv=neg ka ka q mokontomo mokontomo 2pl.pro yaruwari yaruwa -ri laugh-ipfv ‘Ugh, don’t you get tired from laughing so much?’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 23)
  1. wïrë wajyakïtïjra taro wïrë ta wïrë ya wïrë wïrë 1pro wajyakïtï =jra wajyakïtï -∅ =jra be_happy-ipfv=neg taro taro -∅ say-ipfv wïrë wïrë 1pro ta ta -∅ say-ipfv wïrë wïrë 1pro ya ya erg ‘I’m saying I am not happy.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 24)
  1. kajkë kajkë kaj -kë say-imp ‘You’re right.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 25)
  1. ta wejsaj wïrë ta ta -∅ say-ipfv wejsaj wej -saj cop-pst wïrë wïrë 1pro ‘I'm saying...’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 26)
  1. tawaraij wïrë, yaruwakempïnirë, tawaraij tawaraij too wïrë wïrë 1pro yaruwakem =pïnirë yaruwa -∅ -ke -m =pïnirë laugh-acnnmlz-prop-nmlz=neg ‘I’m not like that, I don’t laugh.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 27)
  1. uyïwïj yawë usenejkari sukuri jwama u =yïwïj u =y- ïwïj -∅ 1=lk-house-pert yawë yawë loc u =senejkari u =-ri 1=stay-ipfv sukuri sukuri silently jwama *** ‘I silently stay in my house.’ (Conversación sobre la risa entre GrMe y ElPe : 28)

  1. tawara ma ana këyetajpë, ana papa pan patajpë të tawara tawara too ma ma rst ana ana 1+3pro këyetajpë -jpë grow-pst ana ana 1+3pro papa papa father pan pan fmr patajpë pata -jpë axe-pst të të loc ‘This is how we grew up, in my late father's village.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 17)
  1. papa pano sëmasaj yawë papa papa father pano pano fmr sëmasaj sëma -saj die-abs.nmlz yawë yawë loc ‘Because my dad had died.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 18)
  1. irë ana këyetase tawara ma irë irë 3ana.inan ana ana 1+3pro këyetase -se grow-pst tawara tawara too ma ma rst ‘That's how we grew up.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 19)
  1. sukase ana këyetase pipi yakërë, ana këyetase intipijkë ana chawë sukase sukase all ana ana 1+3pro këyetase -se grow-pst pipi pipi younger_brother_of_woman yakërë y- akërë lk-with ana ana 1+3pro këyetase -se grow-pst intipijkë intipijkë small ana ana 1+3pro chawë chawë loc ‘We grew up with my younger brother; we grew up when we were small.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 20)
  1. ana këyetase makampra ya ana ana 1+3pro këyetase -se grow-pst makampra makampra aunt ya ya obl ‘We grew up with my aunt.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 21)
  1. tëwï ya papa kampra pana tase ta, kaimotata tëwï tëwï 3pro ya ya erg papa papa father kampra kampra big pana pana dat tase ta -se say-pst ta ta like kaimotata -ta hunt-motimp ‘She said to my uncle: "go hunt!".’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 22)
  1. yomiri mukutomo yomiri yomi -ri be_hungry-ipfv mukutomo muku -tomo child-pl ‘"The children are hungry."’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 23)
  1. asamo mare tapëkë ijtëri weroro yarë ta yakuri këjmatojpe asamo asamo -∅ cry-ipfv mare mare rel.inan tapëkë ta -pëkë say-prog.tr ijtëri ij- të -ri 3-go-ipfv weroro weroro dog yarë yarë -∅ bring-ipfv ta ta like yakuri yakuri agouti këjmatojpe këjma -tojpe hunt-purp ‘Because they were crying he went and took the dogs to hunt agouti.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 24)
  1. irë yakuri irë irë 3ana.inan yakuri yakuri agouti ‘Agouti.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 25)
  1. taturu makampra ya ana yoti makë taturu ta- tu -ru 3p-give-ipfv makampra makampra aunt ya ya erg ana ana 1+3pro yoti y- oti -∅ lk-meat-pert makë makë mom ‘My aunt gave her our food.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 26)
  1. ijmokatojpe ijmokatojpe ijmoka -tojpe cook-purp ‘For cooking.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 27)
  1. irëjpë makë ya ijmojka wejsapë irëjpë irëjpë then makë makë mom ya ya erg ijmojka ijmojka -∅ cook-ipfv wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pst ‘Then my mom was cooking.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 28)
  1. ana yoti, yakuri ana ana 1+3pro yoti y- oti -∅ lk-meat-pert yakuri yakuri agouti ‘Our food, agouti.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 29)
  1. makampra ya tujpë makampra makampra aunt ya ya erg tujpë tu -jpë give-pst ‘What my aunt gave her (?).’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 30)
  1. sukase tawara ma ana këyatajpë, onono pëkë sukase sukase all tawara tawara too ma ma rst ana ana 1+3pro këyatajpë -jpë grow-pst onono onono another pëkë pëkë about ‘We were all raised this way, in a different way.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 31)
  1. kïmïi ma yeme ana ya kïmïi kïmïi chili ma ma rst yeme yeme -∅ eat(fruits_eggs_soup)-ipfv ana ana 1+3pro ya ya erg ‘We were just eating chili.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 32)
  1. sere yokïrï, irëjpë sukutaka yeni ana ya sere sere bitter_manioc yokïrï yokï -rï eat(starch)-ipfv irëjpë irëjpë then sukutaka sukutaka yucuta yeni yeni -∅ drink-ipfv ana ana 1+3pro ya ya erg ‘We ate cassava, then we would drink yucuta.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 33)
  1. tëwï kïmïi yemetïkene, ana yeni wejsapë sukutaka ma tëwï tëwï 3pro kïmïi kïmïi chili yemetïkene yeme -tïkene eat(fruits_eggs_soup)-post ana ana 1+3pro yeni yeni -∅ drink-ipfv wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pst sukutaka sukutaka yucuta ma ma rst ‘After eating chili, we would drink yucuta.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 34)
  1. nwarë ana këyatajpë ana nwa =rë nwa =rë thus=emp ana ana 1+3pro këyatajpë -jpë grow-pst ana ana 1+3pro ‘That's how we grew up.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 35)
  1. irëjpë rë neke n ti irëjpë irëjpë then rë rë emp neke =n neke =n cntr=ints ti ti hsy ‘Then, well...’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 36)
  1. makë sepanse makë makë mom sepanse sepan -se get_married-pst ‘My mom got married.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 37)
  1. Rafa Perez pan yakërë rafa rafa R. perez perez P. pan pan fmr yakërë y- akërë lk-with ‘With the late Rafel Perez.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 38)
  1. irëjpë, tëwï yakërë, ana këyatase irëjpë irëjpë then tëwï tëwï 3pro yakërë y- akërë lk-with ana ana 1+3pro këyatase -se grow-pst ‘Then we grew up with him.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 39)
  1. yatampe ana tëse, pipi tawara rë waraijtokompe ijtëse yatam =pe yatam =pe adolescent=ess ana ana 1+3pro tëse të -se go-pst pipi pipi younger_brother_of_woman tawara tawara too rë rë emp waraijtokom =pe waraijtokom =pe man=ess ijtëse ij- të -se 3-go-pst ‘We became adolescents, my brother became a man, too.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 40)
  1. ana këyatase tëwï yakërë ana ana 1+3pro këyatase -se grow-pst tëwï tëwï 3pro yakërë y- akërë lk-with ‘We grew up with him.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 41)
  1. ana padrastro yakërë ana ana 1+3pro padrastro padrastro -∅ stepfather-pert yakërë y- akërë lk-with ‘With our stepfather.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 42)
  1. tëwï ya ana këyamase tëwï tëwï 3pro ya ya erg ana ana 1+3pro këyamase -se raise-pst ‘He raised us.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 43)
  1. muku wëra ana këyamase ta muku muku child wëra wëra like ana ana 1+3pro këyamase -se raise-pst ta ta like ‘He raised us as his own children.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 44)
  1. nopano wejsaj ta waraijtokomo nopano nop -ano good-nmlz wejsaj ? ta ta like waraijtokomo waraijtokomo man ‘This was a good man.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 45)
  1. ana tapaja ta, ana këyatase nope ana ana 1+3pro tapaja tapa -ja beat-neg ta ta like ana ana 1+3pro këyatase -se grow-pst nope nope good ‘He didn't beat us; we were raised well.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 46)
  1. tëwï waraijtokon yakërë, ana këyamase ta wejsapë tëwï tëwï 3pro waraijtokon waraijtokon man yakërë y- akërë lk-with ana ana 1+3pro këyamase -se raise-pst ta ta like wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pst ‘With that man, he raised us.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 47)
  1. takërë ana wejsapë ïmparëjra takërë t- akërë 3-with ana ana 1+3pro wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pst ïmparë =jra ïmparë =jra already=neg ‘We were with him for a long time.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 48)
  1. irëjpë rë warë tajtojpe pïnika wïrë sepanse irëjpë irëjpë then rë rë emp wa =rë wa =rë thus=emp tajtojpe taj -tojpe say-purp pïnika pïnika prob wïrë wïrë 1pro sepanse sepan -se get_married-pst ‘Then, closer tow now, I got married.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 49)
  1. irëjpë irëjpë irëjpë then ‘Then...’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 50)
  1. ana wejsapë ana ana 1+3pro wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pst ‘We were.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 51)
  1. makë yakërë ma wejtane, tëijpë rë pïjkë ana yïwïtï makë makë mom yakërë y- akërë lk-with ma ma rst wejtane wej -tane cop-cncs tëijpë tëijpë far rë rë emp pïjkë -pïjkë dim ana ana 1+3pro yïwïtï y- ïwïtï -∅ lk-house-pert ‘Even though I was with my mom, our house was a bit far away.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 52)
  1. ana yïwïj yawë ana senejka wejsapë, tawara ma ana këyatajpë ana ana ana 1+3pro yïwïj y- ïwïj -∅ lk-house-pert yawë yawë loc ana ana 1+3pro senejka -∅ stay-ipfv wejsapë wej -sapë cop-pst tawara tawara too ma ma rst ana ana 1+3pro këyatajpë -jpë grow-pst ana ana 1+3pro ‘We stayed at home, that's how we were raised.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 53)
  1. papa pano patajpë të papa papa father pano pano fmr patajpë pata -jpë axe-pst të të loc ‘In my late father's village.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 54)
  1. ëmpare ëmpare ëmpare already ‘That's it.’ (Historia personal por AnFo : 55)

  • ana këyetase papa kampra ya, ana yoti wejsapë yojtë ta sukase aroma warai, yakuri warai yojtë wejsaj ta ‘(When) we grew up, my uncle fished our food; fished everything: limpet, picure...’
  • ana këyetase papa kampra ya, ana yoti wejsapë yojtë ta sukase aroma warai, yakuri warai yojtë wejsaj ta ‘(When) we grew up, my uncle fished our food; fished everything: limpet, picure...’
  • ana yoti, ana serematojpe ‘Our food, to eat.’

  • tawara ma ana këyetajpë, ana papa pan patajpë të ‘This is how we grew up, in my late father's village.’
  • tawara ma ana këyetajpë, ana papa pan patajpë të ‘This is how we grew up, in my late father's village.’
  • irë ana këyetase tawara ma ‘That's how we grew up.’
  • sukase ana këyetase pipi yakërë, ana këyetase intipijkë ana chawë ‘We grew up with my younger brother; we grew up when we were small.’

  • sukase ana këyetase pipi yakërë, ana këyetase intipijkë ana chawë ‘We grew up with my younger brother; we grew up when we were small.’
  • ana këyetase makampra ya ‘We grew up with my aunt.’
  • taturu makampra ya ana yoti makë ‘My aunt gave her our food.’
  • ana yoti, yakuri ‘Our food, agouti.’
  • sukase tawara ma ana këyatajpë, onono pëkë ‘We were all raised this way, in a different way.’
  • kïmïi ma yeme ana ya ‘We were just eating chili.’
  • sere yokïrï, irëjpë sukutaka yeni ana ya ‘We ate cassava, then we would drink yucuta.’
  • tëwï kïmïi yemetïkene, ana yeni wejsapë sukutaka ma ‘After eating chili, we would drink yucuta.’
  • nwarë ana këyatajpë ana ‘That's how we grew up.’
  • nwarë ana këyatajpë ana ‘That's how we grew up.’
  • irëjpë, tëwï yakërë, ana këyatase ‘Then we grew up with him.’
  • yatampe ana tëse, pipi tawara rë waraijtokompe ijtëse ‘We became adolescents, my brother became a man, too.’
  • ana këyatase tëwï yakërë ‘We grew up with him.’
  • ana padrastro yakërë ‘With our stepfather.’
  • tëwï ya ana këyamase ‘He raised us.’
  • muku wëra ana këyamase ta ‘He raised us as his own children.’
  • ana tapaja ta, ana këyatase nope ‘He didn't beat us; we were raised well.’
  • ana tapaja ta, ana këyatase nope ‘He didn't beat us; we were raised well.’
  • tëwï waraijtokon yakërë, ana këyamase ta wejsapë ‘With that man, he raised us.’
  • takërë ana wejsapë ïmparëjra ‘We were with him for a long time.’
  • ana wejsapë ‘We were.’
  • makë yakërë ma wejtane, tëijpë rë pïjkë ana yïwïtï ‘Even though I was with my mom, our house was a bit far away.’
  • ana yïwïj yawë ana senejka wejsapë, tawara ma ana këyatajpë ana ‘We stayed at home, that's how we were raised.’

  • wëjkaja, ana tëse neke ne ‘We didn't fall, we went away.’

  • Yawarana chipëkë ‘because‘
  • me-chipeke-2-because-1
  • tawara chipëkë takï wïrë ëmpamïja wejsapë tase wïrë ‘Since it was like that, I did not learn, I said.’
  • inkë, irë nwa chipëkë ‘You see, that’s why.’
  • iyawë chipëkë, tayawankase ‘Because of this, he killed her.’
  • irë wa chipëkë tapojtëja wejsapë, irë wa chipëkë tajne wëpëjse tëwï, sukase wïnïjsajkonton yawë ‘That's why I didn't want it, that's why they killed them all when they were asleep.’
  • irë wa chipëkë tapojtëja wejsapë, irë wa chipëkë tajne wëpëjse tëwï, sukase wïnïjsajkonton yawë ‘That's why I didn't want it, that's why they killed them all when they were asleep.’

docs.text:
• ID: ire-3ana-inan
  • Form: irë
  • Parameter_ID: 3ANA.INAN
  • Morpho_Segments: irë
  • Language: Yawarana
  • Part_of_speech: demonstrative
MorphsExamples
  • Yawarana irë ‘3ANA.INAN‘
  • inkë, irë nwa chipëkë ‘You see, that’s why.’
  • asamori ta wejsaj ta, irë makë ta wejsapë ‘My aunt said "they are crying".’
  • irë ana këyetase tawara ma ‘That's how we grew up.’
  • irë yakuri ‘Agouti.’
  • irë wejtane mujyampe patakaja wejsapë ‘Despite this, she did not get pregnant.’
  • irë wejtane ti ‘Although this was the case,’
  • irë wa chipëkë tapojtëja wejsapë, irë wa chipëkë tajne wëpëjse tëwï, sukase wïnïjsajkonton yawë ‘That's why I didn't want it, that's why they killed them all when they were asleep.’
  • irë wa chipëkë tapojtëja wejsapë, irë wa chipëkë tajne wëpëjse tëwï, sukase wïnïjsajkonton yawë ‘That's why I didn't want it, that's why they killed them all when they were asleep.’
  • irë nwa chipëkë usamori uyïpï incharë ‘That's why I'm crying seeing my hills.’

docs.title: Wordform: irëjpë ‘then’
docs.text:
• ID: irejpe-then
  • Form: irëjpë
  • Parameter_ID: then
  • Morpho_Segments: irëjpë
  • Source: Mattéi-Müller and Cáceres Arandia 2023
  • Media_ID: YarLex_0494_PaPe_irejpe
  • Language: Yawarana
  • Part_of_speech: adverb
MorphsFormpartsExamples
  • Yawarana irëjpë ‘then‘
  • irejpe-ne-then-ints-0
  • ati rë warai mërë iniri, irëjpë mëyarika ti ‘You see something and then you laugh.’
  • tajne yarikari irëjpë, tajne yakarama pokono ‘They laugh because they tell it.’
  • sukase ta wejsaj ta, irëjpë papa kampra ijtëri ‘She said that, then my uncle left’
  • irëjpë sakara nepï wejsaj ta, irëjpë michi ‘He brought guabina, then (he said) "here it is".’
  • irëjpë sakara nepï wejsaj ta, irëjpë michi ‘He brought guabina, then (he said) "here it is".’
  • irëjpë makë ya ijmojka wejsapë ‘Then my mom was cooking.’
  • sere yokïrï, irëjpë sukutaka yeni ana ya ‘We ate cassava, then we would drink yucuta.’
  • irëjpë rë neke n ti ‘Then, well...’
  • irëjpë, tëwï yakërë, ana këyatase ‘Then we grew up with him.’
  • irëjpë rë warë tajtojpe pïnika wïrë sepanse ‘Then, closer tow now, I got married.’
  • irëjpë ‘Then...’
  • irëjpë, kwaraijyawë rë mëëmpamïjpë tajto marë ti? ‘Afterwards, when did you learn what you say?’
  • irëjpë ti ta ti ta ‘Then she said:’
  • tawani yawë senejka wejsapë irëjpë ënujse kawë ‘He was staying in the dark and then went up high.’
  • kawë ënujse irëjpë ‘He went up high and then...’
  • "sakunkai" ta ta irëjpë "sakunkai" ‘“Sakunkai”, they said, and then “Sakunkai”.’
  • irëjpë tëwï waijtatomo nwajtëri ‘Then the mice were dancing.’
  • wenaru pïrarë irëjpë ti ‘There was no vomit.’
  • irëjpë ta ti ta konopo wejsarë konopo wejsarë ‘Then they said: “it’s raining, it’s raining”.’
  • irëjpë pïrarë ti warë irëjpë warë ‘Then there was nothing.’
  • irëjpë pïrarë ti warë irëjpë warë ‘Then there was nothing.’
  • irëjpë tawejka yawë ‘Then, in the morning...’
  • tipasekontomo warë irëjpë pïrarë ‘They left and were gone.’
  • irëjpë ti wenakajpë mare pïrarë ti ‘Then there was nothing of their vomit.’
  • sukase nwajtëri irëjpë ti warë ‘They were all dancing, then.’
  • waraijtokon maniki irëjpë ijtëse ‘Then the man went.’
  • ¿irëjpë, wepïjpëkontomo? ‘Then they came?’

  • makë yakërë ma wejtane, tëijpë rë pïjkë ana yïwïtï ‘Even though I was with my mom, our house was a bit far away.’
  • ana yïwïj yawë ana senejka wejsapë, tawara ma ana këyatajpë ana ‘We stayed at home, that's how we were raised.’
  • mërë ma ejnë waimu yaye mëwaimuru ‘Only your speak in our language.’
  • tëwï ma takï mëyakarama chijpë wararë kwa ta sënkatoj mëtë ‘Tell us again how they ended up there.’
  • tëwï ma tase makë ya ‘That’s what my mother said.’
  • tawara ma ta ti wejsapë tëwï ‘That’s all she said.’
  • tëwï ke ma mëyepema wïrë ya, ta ti ta ‘"I'll pay you only this," he said.’
  • michi ma mëyapëjjrama ‘Do not touch this.’
  • ¿mëpana ma tataja wejsapë? ‘Didn't he say it directly to you?’

  • ¡kï! ¿mokontomo serekapojra ka mokontomo yaruwari? wïrë yaruwarijra taro wïrë, ta ta wïrë ya ‘Oh! You don’t get tired of laughing? I don’t laugh, is what I’m saying.’
  • kï, serekapojra ka mokontomo yaruwari ‘Ugh, don’t you get tired from laughing so much?’
  • ¡kë mokontomo wajyakïtï ta, wïrë wajyakïtïjra taro wïrë ta wïrë ya ‘Ugh, you are happy but I am not, I say.’
  • asanë tanëmëse mërë nono mokontomo warotatojpe ‘Your mother left your land for you to work on.’
  • marë wïrë sëmpinukuja rë wejtane mokontomo unono, wïrë nono yenekapëkë pako ‘Though I haven't closed my eyes yet, you are already taking my land from me.’

docs.title: Wordform: neke ‘cntr’
docs.text:
• ID: neke-cntr
  • Form: neke
  • Parameter_ID: CNTR
  • Morpho_Segments: neke
  • Language: Yawarana
  • Part_of_speech: particle
MorphsFormpartsExamples
  • Yawarana neke ‘CNTR‘
  • neke-ne-cntr-ints-0
  • neke-n-cntr-ints-0
  • ejnë yaruwari tajne yakarama pëkë rë nwarë, nope esene mare, tawara neke ne, ënka ‘We laugh when somebody tells (us) something, something you see well, like that, right.’
  • tëwï neke ne, tajne yakarama pokono nwarë tajne iri mïntë, tunampe ‘Yes indeed, they tell what they are doing there on the down-low.’
  • tawaja ejnë, ejnë neke ne, ejnë pëkëpene ejnë yarikaja ‘We’re not like that, we don’t just laugh.’
  • tëwïsantomo neke ne yaruwatëpëkë ma rë chikontomo ‘But they’re constantly laughing.’
  • kwase neke wejsapë tëwï ma anajmori ya yakarama wejsapë ‘what it was like, that's all your grandmother said.’
  • irëjpë rë neke n ti ‘Then, well...’
  • wëjkaja, ana tëse neke ne ‘We didn't fall, we went away.’
  • yajtëpe neke n ti warotakontomo wejsapë ‘At the beginning they worked.’
  • ajpachi yaka pïnika ëkëjna neke wonse ‘Probably to the woods, who knows where they went.’

docs.title: Wordform: nwa ‘thus’
docs.text:
• ID: nwa-thus
  • Form: nwa
  • Parameter_ID: thus
  • Morpho_Segments: nwa
  • Language: Yawarana
  • Part_of_speech: particle
MorphsFormpartsExamples
  • Yawarana nwa ‘thus‘
  • nwa-re-thus-emp-0
  • ejnë yaruwari tajne yakarama pëkë rë nwarë, nope esene mare, tawara neke ne, ënka ‘We laugh when somebody tells (us) something, something you see well, like that, right.’
  • tëwï neke ne, tajne yakarama pokono nwarë tajne iri mïntë, tunampe ‘Yes indeed, they tell what they are doing there on the down-low.’
  • nwarë ti ta ta ‘That’s what they said (?)’
  • inkë, irë nwa chipëkë ‘You see, that’s why.’
  • mërë nwa chipokono ejnë yarikaja ‘That’s why we don’t laugh.’
  • nwa ma pïnika ta wïrë ya ‘So I won’t say any more.’
  • nwa ma ta wïrë ya ‘That’s all I’m saying.’
  • nwarë ana këyatajpë ana ‘That's how we grew up.’
  • ta-ta ta-ta, nwarë ejnë weseyu wëra rë, ejnë tapa ta ‘ta-ta-ta, like that he rubbed us as if he was angry with us.’
  • irë nwa chipëkë usamori uyïpï incharë ‘That's why I'm crying seeing my hills.’
  • nwarë mëtëpëtiri, tëpëtijra sejkë ‘You're going to go like this? Don't go like this.’

docs.title: Wordform: papa ‘father’
docs.text:

  • ana këyetase papa kampra ya, ana yoti wejsapë yojtë ta sukase aroma warai, yakuri warai yojtë wejsaj ta ‘(When) we grew up, my uncle fished our food; fished everything: limpet, picure...’
  • papa kampra ya, makampra ya ta wejsaj ta, maijtë kaimotata, mukuton yomiri ‘My aunt said to my uncle: “go hunt, the children are hungry”.’
  • sukase ta wejsaj ta, irëjpë papa kampra ijtëri ‘She said that, then my uncle left’
  • tawara ma ana këyetajpë, ana papa pan patajpë të ‘This is how we grew up, in my late father's village.’
  • papa pano sëmasaj yawë ‘Because my dad had died.’
  • tëwï ya papa kampra pana tase ta, kaimotata ‘She said to my uncle: "go hunt!".’
  • papa pano patajpë të ‘In my late father's village.’

  • mëyaruwari, mëpëkëpene ‘You just laugh.’
  • ejnë pëkëpene ejnë yaruwaja, ënka wanene ‘We don’t just laugh, right, aunt?’
  • tawaja ejnë, ejnë neke ne, ejnë pëkëpene ejnë yarikaja ‘We’re not like that, we don’t just laugh.’
  • aniki narëpe yakërë ejnë përemekïrï, ejnë pëkëpene, wanene ‘Who are we gonna talk to? We’re alone, aunt.’
  • ejnë pëkëpene ejnë chi yawë, ejnë yarikaja ‘When we’re alone, we don’t laugh.’
  • tëjrama sejkë upëkëpene wïrë tëri ‘Don't go, I will go alone.’

  • Yawarana pïnika ‘PROB‘
  • tajne ya ijpë mare tëwï, tajne ya yekerema pïnika ta wïrë ‘What they did, they’re going to tell, I say’
  • pïnika, pïnika, tawara chipokon pïnika yaruwakontomo ‘So that’s why they’re laughing.’
  • pïnika, pïnika, tawara chipokon pïnika yaruwakontomo ‘So that’s why they’re laughing.’
  • pïnika, pïnika, tawara chipokon pïnika yaruwakontomo ‘So that’s why they’re laughing.’
  • nwa ma pïnika ta wïrë ya ‘So I won’t say any more.’
  • tejetum pïnika, ta wejsaj ta makë ya, makë pano ya ‘"That one is probably sick", said my mother, my late mother.’
  • irëjpë rë warë tajtojpe pïnika wïrë sepanse ‘Then, closer tow now, I got married.’
  • tayakïjtëja pïnika wejsapë ‘Maybe he didn't sleep with her.’
  • ajpachi yaka pïnika ëkëjna neke wonse ‘Probably to the woods, who knows where they went.’
  • tëwï ajpachi yaka wonse pïnika tëwï ‘Maybe they went to the woods.’

  • pïrarë ejnë chiyakon chipokono ejnë yaruwatopo pïrarë ‘Because we don’t have friends we don’t have anything to laugh.’

  • pïrarë ‘Nothing.’
  • pïrarë ti iwenaru wejsapë ‘their vomit was not there.’
  • wenaru pïrarë irëjpë ti ‘There was no vomit.’
  • irëjpë pïrarë ti warë irëjpë warë ‘Then there was nothing.’
  • tipasekontomo warë irëjpë pïrarë ‘They left and were gone.’
  • irëjpë ti wenakajpë mare pïrarë ti ‘Then there was nothing of their vomit.’
  • ëkï ta rë pïrarë wenarujpë ta rë pïrarë ‘The chicha was gone and so was the vomit.’

MorphsFormpartsExamples
  • Yawarana rë ‘EMP‘

  • wa-re-thus-emp-1
  • re-re-emp-emp-0
  • re-re-emp-emp-1
  • i-re-put-ipfv-emp-1

  • asakere-re-two-emp-1
  • apo-no-re-later-nmlz-emp-1

  • wara-re-thus-emp-1
  • ati rë warai mërë iniri, irëjpë mëyarika ti ‘You see something and then you laugh.’
  • ejnë yaruwari tajne yakarama pëkë rë nwarë, nope esene mare, tawara neke ne, ënka ‘We laugh when somebody tells (us) something, something you see well, like that, right.’
  • ejnë yaruwari tajne yakarama pëkë rë nwarë, nope esene mare, tawara neke ne, ënka ‘We laugh when somebody tells (us) something, something you see well, like that, right.’
  • tëwï neke ne, tajne yakarama pokono nwarë tajne iri mïntë, tunampe ‘Yes indeed, they tell what they are doing there on the down-low.’
  • nwarë ti ta ta ‘That’s what they said (?)’
  • tëwïsantomo neke ne yaruwatëpëkë ma rë chikontomo ‘But they’re constantly laughing.’
  • wïrë inija ta rë ‘I haven’t seen.’
  • mërë warë mëyënëtojpano ka uyakërë mërë wepïrï ‘So for you to eat you came with me?’
  • wïrë tawara rë entë ‘I was here (in San Juan Manapiare).’
  • irë makë ya ijmojka wejsapë ‘Then my mom was cooking.’
  • nwarë ana këyatajpë ana ‘That's how we grew up.’
  • irëjpë rë neke n ti ‘Then, well...’
  • yatampe ana tëse, pipi tawara rë waraijtokompe ijtëse ‘We became adolescents, my brother became a man, too.’
  • irëjpë rë warë tajtojpe pïnika wïrë sepanse ‘Then, closer tow now, I got married.’
  • irëjpë rë warë tajtojpe pïnika wïrë sepanse ‘Then, closer tow now, I got married.’
  • makë yakërë ma wejtane, tëijpë rë pïjkë ana yïwïtï ‘Even though I was with my mom, our house was a bit far away.’
  • asakërërë mëyawajkë, asakë mëyumukunu ‘Scrape with both, two hands.’
  • wurijyantomo rë wejsapë ijtë ‘There were only women there.’
  • tëwï ma takï mëyakarama chijpë wararë kwa ta sënkatoj mëtë ‘Tell us again how they ended up there.’
  • irëjpë, kwaraijyawë rë mëëmpamïjpë tajto marë ti? ‘Afterwards, when did you learn what you say?’
  • pïtïpëjsapë chipë ke, pïtï, pïtï, pïtï, warë ‘Painted with caranna, painted all over.’
  • makë ya ta taji rë ‘My mother told this (story).’
  • enijpëtërë waraijtokomo ijtëse ti mïjna tëijpo wïnïjse ‘A man went there, far, to sleep.’
  • wurijyampïjkë kantajnë tawara rë wejsapë ‘The female was singing, too.’
  • tajne naijpëtiri warë ‘They did like this.’
  • warë sujtase ‘Then he urinated.’
  • irëjpë pïrarë ti warë irëjpë warë ‘Then there was nothing.’
  • irëjpë pïrarë ti warë irëjpë warë ‘Then there was nothing.’
  • tipasekontomo warë irëjpë pïrarë ‘They left and were gone.’
  • ëkï ta rë pïrarë wenarujpë ta rë pïrarë ‘The chicha was gone and so was the vomit.’
  • ëkï ta rë pïrarë wenarujpë ta rë pïrarë ‘The chicha was gone and so was the vomit.’
  • sukase nwajtëri irëjpë ti warë ‘They were all dancing, then.’
  • tichikimuru, peti warë patakasapë Yakucho pana ‘His knee, his leg went out towards Ayacucho.’
  • ta-ta ta-ta, nwarë ejnë weseyu wëra rë, ejnë tapa ta ‘ta-ta-ta, like that he rubbed us as if he was angry with us.’
  • ta-ta ta-ta, nwarë ejnë weseyu wëra rë, ejnë tapa ta ‘ta-ta-ta, like that he rubbed us as if he was angry with us.’
  • takonojpë rë yapijtontomo ya, najpïtom pan yakono wïrë inijpë chipëkën takï wïrë taro ‘The last old ones, the younger brother of my grandparents, because I saw them, I say so.’
  • marë wïrë sëmpinukuja rë wejtane mokontomo unono, wïrë nono yenekapëkë pako ‘Though I haven't closed my eyes yet, you are already taking my land from me.’
  • nwarë mëtëpëtiri, tëpëtijra sejkë ‘You're going to go like this? Don't go like this.’
  • ejnë waimu wintikasarë ta rë ‘Our language is disappearing.’
  • wïrë najpïtomojne, wurijyantomojne sënka wara rë ‘My grandfathers, the women disappeared.’

docs.text:

  • Yawarana sukase ‘all‘
  • ana këyetase papa kampra ya, ana yoti wejsapë yojtë ta sukase aroma warai, yakuri warai yojtë wejsaj ta ‘(When) we grew up, my uncle fished our food; fished everything: limpet, picure...’
  • sukase ta wejsaj ta, irëjpë papa kampra ijtëri ‘She said that, then my uncle left’
  • sukase ana këyetase pipi yakërë, ana këyetase intipijkë ana chawë ‘We grew up with my younger brother; we grew up when we were small.’
  • sukase tawara ma ana këyatajpë, onono pëkë ‘We were all raised this way, in a different way.’
  • sukase nwajtëri irëjpë ti warë ‘They were all dancing, then.’
  • irë wa chipëkë tapojtëja wejsapë, irë wa chipëkë tajne wëpëjse tëwï, sukase wïnïjsajkonton yawë ‘That's why I didn't want it, that's why they killed them all when they were asleep.’

MorphsFormpartsExamples

  • ejnë yaruwari tajne yakarama pëkë rë nwarë, nope esene mare, tawara neke ne, ënka ‘We laugh when somebody tells (us) something, something you see well, like that, right.’
  • tëwï neke ne, tajne yakarama pokono nwarë tajne iri mïntë, tunampe ‘Yes indeed, they tell what they are doing there on the down-low.’
  • tëwï neke ne, tajne yakarama pokono nwarë tajne iri mïntë, tunampe ‘Yes indeed, they tell what they are doing there on the down-low.’
  • tajne yarikari irëjpë, tajne yakarama pokono ‘They laugh because they tell it.’
  • tajne yarikari irëjpë, tajne yakarama pokono ‘They laugh because they tell it.’
  • tajne ini pokono waimukontomo ‘Because they see, they speak.’
  • tajne ya ijpë mare tëwï, tajne ya yekerema pïnika ta wïrë ‘What they did, they’re going to tell, I say’
  • tajne ya ijpë mare tëwï, tajne ya yekerema pïnika ta wïrë ‘What they did, they’re going to tell, I say’
  • okï yëni tajne ya soj soj soj ‘They drank chicha, glug glug.’
  • tajne naijpëtiri warë ‘They did like this.’
  • tajne nankase takerejtomo ya ‘His relatives found him.’
  • irë wa chipëkë tapojtëja wejsapë, irë wa chipëkë tajne wëpëjse tëwï, sukase wïnïjsajkonton yawë ‘That's why I didn't want it, that's why they killed them all when they were asleep.’

docs.title: Wordform: ta ‘like’
docs.text:
• ID: ta-like
  • Form: ta
  • Parameter_ID: like
  • Morpho_Segments: ta
  • Language: Yawarana
  • Part_of_speech: particle
MorphsFormpartsExamples
  • Yawarana ta ‘like‘
  • ta-ne-like-ints-0
  • ¡kï! ¿mokontomo serekapojra ka mokontomo yaruwari? wïrë yaruwarijra taro wïrë, ta ta wïrë ya ‘Oh! You don’t get tired of laughing? I don’t laugh, is what I’m saying.’
  • nwarë ti ta ta ‘That’s what they said (?)’
  • ¿ati ta ta? ‘What are you saying?’
  • ta takontomo ‘That’s what they say (?)’
  • wïrë inija ta rë ‘I haven’t seen.’
  • ¡kë mokontomo wajyakïtï ta, wïrë wajyakïtïjra taro wïrë ta wïrë ya ‘Ugh, you are happy but I am not, I say.’
  • ana këyetase papa kampra ya, ana yoti wejsapë yojtë ta sukase aroma warai, yakuri warai yojtë wejsaj ta ‘(When) we grew up, my uncle fished our food; fished everything: limpet, picure...’
  • ana këyetase papa kampra ya, ana yoti wejsapë yojtë ta sukase aroma warai, yakuri warai yojtë wejsaj ta ‘(When) we grew up, my uncle fished our food; fished everything: limpet, picure...’
  • papa kampra ya, makampra ya ta wejsaj ta, maijtë kaimotata, mukuton yomiri ‘My aunt said to my uncle: “go hunt, the children are hungry”.’
  • asamori ta wejsaj ta, irë makë ta wejsapë ‘My aunt said "they are crying".’
  • sukase ta wejsaj ta, irëjpë papa kampra ijtëri ‘She said that, then my uncle left’
  • irëjpë sakara nepï wejsaj ta, irëjpë michi ‘He brought guabina, then (he said) "here it is".’
  • yakono ijmojkakë mukuton yoti ta wejsaj ta ‘Then she said, "sister cook for the children to eat"’
  • tëwï ya papa kampra pana tase ta, kaimotata ‘She said to my uncle: "go hunt!".’
  • asamo mare tapëkë ijtëri weroro yarë ta yakuri këjmatojpe ‘Because they were crying he went and took the dogs to hunt agouti.’
  • muku wëra ana këyamase ta ‘He raised us as his own children.’
  • nopano wejsaj ta waraijtokomo ‘This was a good man.’
  • ana tapaja ta, ana këyatase nope ‘He didn't beat us; we were raised well.’
  • tëwï waraijtokon yakërë, ana këyamase ta wejsapë ‘With that man, he raised us.’
  • aniki ta uyeremari ‘Who was going to feed me then?’
  • chayi, muku tase ta makë pano ya ‘"Sons, daughters" said my late mother.’
  • tëwï ma takï mëyakarama chijpë wararë kwa ta sënkatoj mëtë ‘Tell us again how they ended up there.’
  • irëjpë ti ta ti ta ‘Then she said:’
  • "sakunkai" ta ta irëjpë "sakunkai" ‘“Sakunkai”, they said, and then “Sakunkai”.’
  • ta ti ta tëwï waraijtokomo ya ‘said the man (?).’
  • aaa usukuru morone ta, wïrë usujta ta ne ‘My urine hurts, I will urinate.’
  • aaa usukuru morone ta, wïrë usujta ta ne ‘My urine hurts, I will urinate.’
  • irëjpë ta ti ta konopo wejsarë konopo wejsarë ‘Then they said: “it’s raining, it’s raining”.’
  • ta ti ta waijtatomo ya ‘...said the mice.’
  • ëkï ta rë pïrarë wenarujpë ta rë pïrarë ‘The chicha was gone and so was the vomit.’
  • ëkï ta rë pïrarë wenarujpë ta rë pïrarë ‘The chicha was gone and so was the vomit.’
  • aaa, ijtarijra ta ‘Ah, without his legs.’
  • tëwï ke ma mëyepema wïrë ya, ta ti ta ‘"I'll pay you only this," he said.’
  • ta-ta ta-ta, nwarë ejnë weseyu wëra rë, ejnë tapa ta ‘ta-ta-ta, like that he rubbed us as if he was angry with us.’
  • pata penarëjpë mëtë ta, mërë Cerro Muñeca tajtoj mare toto ya ‘Here you can see the village where they lived, what the Criollos call Cerro Muñeca.’
  • ejnë waimu wintikasarë ta rë ‘Our language is disappearing.’

  • asamori ta wejsaj ta, irë makë ta wejsapë ‘My aunt said "they are crying".’
  • tejetum pïnika, ta wejsaj ta makë ya, makë pano ya ‘"That one is probably sick", said my mother, my late mother.’
  • tejetum pïnika, ta wejsaj ta makë ya, makë pano ya ‘"That one is probably sick", said my mother, my late mother.’
  • sukase ta wejsaj ta, irëjpë papa kampra ijtëri ‘She said that, then my uncle left’

  • ë'ë, tawara takï chapëtiri tëwï ‘Yes, he also shouts that.’
  • pachi, kërë takï yëmi pïnirë ‘"sister, that one is not hungry".’
  • tëwï ma takï mëyakarama chijpë wararë kwa ta sënkatoj mëtë ‘Tell us again how they ended up there.’
  • takonojpë rë yapijtontomo ya, najpïtom pan yakono wïrë inijpë chipëkën takï wïrë taro ‘The last old ones, the younger brother of my grandparents, because I saw them, I say so.’

docs.title: Wordform: taro ‘say-ipfv’
docs.text:
• ID: taro-say-ipfv
  • Form: taro
  • Parameter_ID: say-IPFV
  • Morpho_Segments: taro-∅
  • Language: Yawarana
  • Part_of_speech: transitive verb
MorphsFormpartsExamples
  • Yawarana taro ‘say‘
  • Yawarana -∅ ‘IPFV‘
  • wire-1pro-taro-say-ipfv-taro-say-ipfv-2
  • tewi-3pro-taro-say-ipfv-taro-say-ipfv-2
  • taro-jra-say-ipfv-neg-0
  • ana-1-3pro-taro-say-ipfv-taro-say-ipfv-2
  • ¡kï! ¿mokontomo serekapojra ka mokontomo yaruwari? wïrë yaruwarijra taro wïrë, ta ta wïrë ya ‘Oh! You don’t get tired of laughing? I don’t laugh, is what I’m saying.’
  • chiri ma wïrë taro ‘That’s all I’m saying.’
  • tawarama taro wïrë, wïrë yewenke ‘That’s all I’m saying, too, I don’t know.’
  • wïrë wajyakïtïjra taro wïrë ta wïrë ya ‘I’m saying I am not happy.’
  • taro mare wïrë ya ‘I'm just saying.’
  • ¡kë mokontomo wajyakïtï ta, wïrë wajyakïtïjra taro wïrë ta wïrë ya ‘Ugh, you are happy but I am not, I say.’
  • takonojpë rë yapijtontomo ya, najpïtom pan yakono wïrë inijpë chipëkën takï wïrë taro ‘The last old ones, the younger brother of my grandparents, because I saw them, I say so.’

docs.title: Wordform: tawara ‘too’
docs.text:
• ID: tawara-too
  • Form: tawara
  • Parameter_ID: too
  • Morpho_Segments: tawara
  • Language: Yawarana
  • Part_of_speech: adverb
MorphsFormpartsExamples
  • Yawarana tawara ‘too‘
  • tawara-ma-too-rst-0
  • tawara-jra-too-neg-0
  • tawara-ne-too-ints-0
  • inijpë tawara, inijpë ‘They saw it too, they saw it.’
  • tawara chipëkë takï wïrë ëmpamïja wejsapë tase wïrë ‘Since it was like that, I did not learn, I said.’
  • ejnë yaruwari tajne yakarama pëkë rë nwarë, nope esene mare, tawara neke ne, ënka ‘We laugh when somebody tells (us) something, something you see well, like that, right.’
  • tawarama taro wïrë, wïrë yewenke ‘That’s all I’m saying, too, I don’t know.’
  • pïnika, pïnika, tawara chipokon pïnika yaruwakontomo ‘So that’s why they’re laughing.’
  • tawarama wïrë itari onono parë ‘I also listened some times.’
  • ë'ë, tawara takï chapëtiri tëwï ‘Yes, he also shouts that.’
  • wïrë tawara rë entë ‘I was here (in San Juan Manapiare).’
  • tawara ma ana këyetajpë, ana papa pan patajpë të ‘This is how we grew up, in my late father's village.’
  • irë ana këyetase tawara ma ‘That's how we grew up.’
  • sukase tawara ma ana këyatajpë, onono pëkë ‘We were all raised this way, in a different way.’
  • yatampe ana tëse, pipi tawara rë waraijtokompe ijtëse ‘We became adolescents, my brother became a man, too.’
  • ana yïwïj yawë ana senejka wejsapë, tawara ma ana këyatajpë ana ‘We stayed at home, that's how we were raised.’
  • tawara wïrë tase tëpana ‘So I told her.’
  • wurijyampïjkë kantajnë tawara rë wejsapë ‘The female was singing, too.’
  • tëwï naikonton ti tawara ‘They did like this.’
  • tawara ma ta ti wejsapë tëwï ‘That’s all she said.’

  • ati ke ejnë yoti yamanë wejsapë tëwï ‘With that we used to prepare the meat.’
  • tëwï ya nepïjpë wejsapë ‘He brought it.’
  • tëwï neke ne, tajne yakarama pokono nwarë tajne iri mïntë, tunampe ‘Yes indeed, they tell what they are doing there on the down-low.’
  • tajne ya ijpë mare tëwï, tajne ya yekerema pïnika ta wïrë ‘What they did, they’re going to tell, I say’
  • kwase neke wejsapë tëwï ma anajmori ya yakarama wejsapë ‘what it was like, that's all your grandmother said.’
  • ë'ë, tawara takï chapëtiri tëwï ‘Yes, he also shouts that.’
  • tëwï ya papa kampra pana tase ta, kaimotata ‘She said to my uncle: "go hunt!".’
  • tëwï kïmïi yemetïkene, ana yeni wejsapë sukutaka ma ‘After eating chili, we would drink yucuta.’
  • irëjpë, tëwï yakërë, ana këyatase ‘Then we grew up with him.’
  • ana këyatase tëwï yakërë ‘We grew up with him.’
  • tëwï ya ana këyamase ‘He raised us.’
  • tëwï waraijtokon yakërë, ana këyamase ta wejsapë ‘With that man, he raised us.’
  • tëwï nwajtënëpëkë ‘He was dancing.’
  • tëwï wïrë inija ‘I didn't see that.’
  • tëwï ma takï mëyakarama chijpë wararë kwa ta sënkatoj mëtë ‘Tell us again how they ended up there.’
  • tëwï naikonton ti tawara ‘They did like this.’
  • irëjpë tëwï waijtatomo nwajtëri ‘Then the mice were dancing.’
  • ta ti ta tëwï waraijtokomo ya ‘said the man (?).’
  • ëjwenakajpë tainpëtiri waraijtokomo tëwï ‘The man saw their vomit.’
  • ta ti wejsaj ti tëwï ‘...he said.’
  • tëwï ajpachi yaka wonse pïnika tëwï ‘Maybe they went to the woods.’
  • tëwï ajpachi yaka wonse pïnika tëwï ‘Maybe they went to the woods.’
  • tëwï ma tase makë ya ‘That’s what my mother said.’
  • tawara ma ta ti wejsapë tëwï ‘That’s all she said.’
  • tëwï ke ma mëyepema wïrë ya, ta ti ta ‘"I'll pay you only this," he said.’
  • kukurujra tëwï ‘They didn't answer.’
  • irë wa chipëkë tapojtëja wejsapë, irë wa chipëkë tajne wëpëjse tëwï, sukase wïnïjsajkonton yawë ‘That's why I didn't want it, that's why they killed them all when they were asleep.’
  • wïrë inija tëwï ‘I did not see that.’

docs.title: Wordform: ti ‘hsy’
docs.text:
• ID: ti-hsy
  • Form: ti
  • Parameter_ID: HSY
  • Morpho_Segments: ti
  • Language: Yawarana
  • Part_of_speech: particle
MorphsFormpartsExamples
  • Yawarana ti ‘HSY‘
  • ti-ne-hsy-ints-0
  • ati rë warai mërë iniri, irëjpë mëyarika ti ‘You see something and then you laugh.’
  • nwarë ti ta ta ‘That’s what they said (?)’
  • taitapo ti ‘I want to hear it.’
  • muku pana yënënijpë ti ‘The one who ate a child's ear, so they say.’
  • irëjpë rë neke n ti ‘Then, well...’
  • ¿kwase ne wepïjpëkonton ti? ta ‘"How did they come?", s/he says.’
  • yajtëpe neke n ti warotakontomo wejsapë ‘At the beginning they worked.’
  • irëjpë, kwaraijyawë rë mëëmpamïjpë tajto marë ti? ‘Afterwards, when did you learn what you say?’
  • enijpëtërë waraijtokomo ijtëse ti mïjna tëijpo wïnïjse ‘A man went there, far, to sleep.’
  • irëjpë ti ta ti ta ‘Then she said:’
  • irëjpë ti ta ti ta ‘Then she said:’
  • ti waijtaton nwajtë wejsapë ‘The mice were dancing.’
  • tëwï naikonton ti tawara ‘They did like this.’
  • irë wejtane ti ‘Although this was the case,’
  • pïrarë ti iwenaru wejsapë ‘their vomit was not there.’
  • wenaru pïrarë irëjpë ti ‘There was no vomit.’
  • ta ti ta tëwï waraijtokomo ya ‘said the man (?).’
  • sujtase ti wejsapë ‘He urinated.’
  • irëjpë ta ti ta konopo wejsarë konopo wejsarë ‘Then they said: “it’s raining, it’s raining”.’
  • ta ti ta waijtatomo ya ‘...said the mice.’
  • irëjpë pïrarë ti warë irëjpë warë ‘Then there was nothing.’
  • waijtatomojpë ijtëse ti ‘The mice went away.’
  • waraijtokomo ya inpëti ti ‘He saw it.’
  • irëjpë ti wenakajpë mare pïrarë ti ‘Then there was nothing of their vomit.’
  • irëjpë ti wenakajpë mare pïrarë ti ‘Then there was nothing of their vomit.’
  • ta ti wejsaj ti tëwï ‘...he said.’
  • ta ti wejsaj ti tëwï ‘...he said.’
  • ëjtë kërëjpë yawë nwajtëkonton ti wejsapë waijta ‘In the old house the mice were dancing.’
  • sukase nwajtëri irëjpë ti warë ‘They were all dancing, then.’
  • tawara ma ta ti wejsapë tëwï ‘That’s all she said.’
  • tëwï ke ma mëyepema wïrë ya, ta ti ta ‘"I'll pay you only this," he said.’

docs.text:

  • ati rë warai mërë iniri, irëjpë mëyarika ti ‘You see something and then you laugh.’
  • ana këyetase papa kampra ya, ana yoti wejsapë yojtë ta sukase aroma warai, yakuri warai yojtë wejsaj ta ‘(When) we grew up, my uncle fished our food; fished everything: limpet, picure...’
  • ana këyetase papa kampra ya, ana yoti wejsapë yojtë ta sukase aroma warai, yakuri warai yojtë wejsaj ta ‘(When) we grew up, my uncle fished our food; fished everything: limpet, picure...’
  • mëinija ka, aniki pinchi, tënësem warai yichapë, okonotojpe ‘You have not seen a fish that is put on to dry.’

  • nopano wejsaj ta waraijtokomo ‘This was a good man.’
  • enijpëtërë waraijtokomo ijtëse ti mïjna tëijpo wïnïjse ‘A man went there, far, to sleep.’
  • ta ti ta tëwï waraijtokomo ya ‘said the man (?).’
  • ëjwenakajpë tainpëtiri waraijtokomo tëwï ‘The man saw their vomit.’
  • waraijtokomo ya inpëti ti ‘He saw it.’
  • tïwïj yaka waraijtokomo manikijpë ‘The man went to his house.’
